intro: Aethionema marginatum, commonly known as the Armenian carnation, is a flowering plant belonging to the Brassicaceae family. It is native to the mountains of Armenia and Turkey, where it thrives in rocky, well-drained soils. The plant produces small, showy flowers in shades of pink, white, and purple, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are narrow and slightly hairy, and it is often cultivated as an ornamental plant due to its hardiness and attractive appearance. Aethionema marginatum is also valued for its ability to tolerate harsh environmental conditions.
